docs.lead_paragraph: If Zolton Williams had been typical of last spring's graduates at Columbia University Law School, he would now be applying for admission to the bar. But Mr. Williams is not typical. He is behind bars, his once promising legal career in ashes. He waits in a Federal jail in Brooklyn to be sentenced to up to 12 years in prison for smuggling tens of thousands of dollars' worth of cocaine from Jamaica to the United States while he was a student at one of the nation's leading law schools.

headline.main: Prosecutors Detail Columbia Law Student's Secret Life as a Criminal

docs.abstract: Article discusses criminal activities of Zolton Williams, 1998 graduate of Columbia University Law School; he is currently in Federal jail in Brooklyn awaiting sentencing to up to 12 years in prison for smuggling tens of thousands of dollars worth of cocaine from Jamaica to United States while he was student; reaction of professors and classmates to charges against Williams noted; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ALL happy people have steady incomes, but every unhappy person is a paycheck short each month. Leo Tolstoy didn't add that observation to his assessment that all happy families are alike, but many parents could have. At no time does this unspoken maxim hang in the air more heavily than during the holidays, when families gather around Jell-O molds and eggnog, firing off questions as if they were prosecutors in an impeachment inquiry: Are you seeing anyone? Is it serious? Does he make a good living? And how good is yours?

headline.main: Free Spirits at the Family Table

docs.abstract: Abby Ellin (Preludes) article on parental concern about jobs and income of their children, which she says is one of the more often-voiced questions at holiday time (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS day faded into night on a recent Sunday, people began streaming into the 13-month-old New Jersey Performing Arts Center in downtown Newark for the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's 4 P.M. Christmas show. Instead of passing by New Jersey's largest city, long a symbol of urban decay, more than 2,000 patrons -- young and old, black and white, well-to-do and working class -- were pouring into its heart. The scene captured a potential for change that even the most ardent supporters of Newark's current revival are quick to admit seemed almost unimaginable three years ago in this city, which was brought to its knees by race riots some 31 years ago.
docs.abstract: Sales of office buildings and rising office rents are signs of progress in Newark, NJ, long symbol of urban decay; investors are buying older, mostly vacant buildings in downtown area and upgrading them to attract tenants; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: VERY so often, late at night, David L. Woodland steals away to the den of his home in Aberdeen, Wash., so that he can check stock prices on the Internet. Mr. Woodland, a 68-year-old retired insurance salesman, delights at how, with the click of a mouse, he can tap into the facts and fortunes of Wall Street. ''If I get a bright idea late at night,'' Mr. Woodland said, ''I go into the office, fire up the computer and put a buy or sell order in.''

headline.main: On-Line Traders: Older, Wiser and Richer

docs.abstract: While on-line trading is popularly regarded as province of day traders in their 20's and 30's, such trading has been joined by persons older than age 50; Microsoft Corp says more than 20 percent of people who use its popular Microsoft Investor software are over age 50, and E-trade, fast-growing on-line brokerage, says quarter of its customers are over 55, up 19 percent from June 1997; profiles of three over-age-50 on-line day traders (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many Americans voiced anger, disgust and frustration with the proceedings. Some radiated grim satisfaction. But as President Clinton's long, painful journey from scandal to impeachment ended yesterday, most Americans were just benumbed, inoculated by the seemingly endless months of lies, legalisms and disillusionment with politics, Washington-style. As the House cast the fateful votes to send perjury and other charges against Mr. Clinton to the Senate for trial, countless Americans paid scant attention, opting for football on television or Christmas shopping, a reflection of polls that had shown that the people overwhelmingly opposed an impeachment that was a forgone conclusion and were sick of the whole mess.

headline.main: Americans Benumbed By the Crisis In the Capital

docs.abstract: Many Americans voice anger, disgust and frustration over impeachment of Pres Clinton, while others radiate grim satisfaction; are benumbed by seemingly endless months of lies, legalisms and disillusionment with politics Washington-style; most deplore Clinton's behavior in trying to cover up affair with Monica Lewinsky but oppose impeachment, calling it excessive punishment that is perhaps harmful to nation; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SGS Holding S.A., a customs inspector for 140 countries, will cut 3,500 jobs and shed its insurance and health care units as it tries to rebound from the loss of government contracts in recession-stricken Asia. SGS, a Geneva-based company that once earned as much as three-quarters of its profit monitoring imports and exports, said the reorganization would result in a 1998 loss of about 300 million Swiss francs ($222 million). It expects a profit of as much as 100 million francs next year.

headline.main: Swiss Company Will Cut Jobs and Shed 2 Units

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the House debate today on article of impeachment against President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency: Nita M. Lowey Democrat of New York I rise in strong opposition to the resolution. Our founding fathers viewed impeachment as a mechanism of last resort to protect the nation from a President who threatened the Constitution or the American people. Throughout our history, members of Congress have appreciated the enormous gravity of impeachment, and that is why despite countless disputes, provocations, misdeeds and lies, the House has voted just once in its history to impeach a President. Indeed, the delicate system of constitutional checks and balances established by the founders works only insofar as each branch of Government exercises its prerogatives responsibly. In the case of impeachment, that means applying the most rigorous test to the use of our authority. The Constitution gives this body the ability to undo our only national election, but we must use that authority judiciously and cautiously. To do otherwise imperils the stability of our democracy, replacing the orderly transfer of power with the constant threat of political upheaval.

headline.main: The Debate on Articles of Impeachment Against President Clinton

docs.abstract: Excerpts from statements by members of Congress during House debate over articles of impeachment against Pres Clinton; includes statements by Reprs Nita M Lowey, Carolyn C Kilpatrick, Edward J Markey, Howard Coble, James C Greenwood, Bernard Sanders, James F Sensenbrenner Jr, Ernest J Istook Jr, Luis V Gutierrez, Bill Delahunt, Jay Dickey, John Thune, John Edward Porter, Bruce F Vento, Marge Roukema, Ron Packard, Charles B Rangel, Charlie Norwood (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rightchoice Managed Care Inc. said yesterday that Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas City had expressed interest in acquiring it for about $278 million as an alternative to a settlement that Rightchoice and its parent, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Missouri, reached with the State of Missouri. Rightchoice said Blue Cross proposed paying $13.50 a share for the public's class A shares of Rightchoice and $15.25 a share for the parent company's class B shares. Rightchoice's publicly traded shares rose 23 percent, gaining $2.0625 each, to $10.9375.

headline.main: RIGHTCHOICE SHARES UP 23% ON NEWS OF BLUE CROSS OFFER

docs.lead_paragraph: Amid the many skeptical voices about the timing of the air strikes against Iraq, few were blunter or quicker on the draw than that of Gerald B. H. Solomon, the chairman of the House Rules Committee and the Representative from this gentle land of horse farms and mineral spas. ''Never underestimate a desperate President,'' he declared, as cruise missiles began to rain on Baghdad. ''It is obvious he is doing it for political reasons.'' But as snow drizzled on the largely Republican Hudson Valley today, Mr. Solomon's constituents had an equally chilly reaction to his claim. The combination of a reservoir of affection for the President and an instinctive protectiveness for the nation's young fighters seem to have put American cynicism at least temporarily on hold.

headline.main: Back Home, Clinton Critic Is Told to Ease Up

docs.abstract: Rep Gerald B H Solomon was among first to question timing of air strikes against Iraq; Solomon's constituents in Saratoga County, NY, disagree with him; combination of reservoir of affection for Pres Clinton and instinctive protectiveness for nation's young fighters seem to have put American cynicism on hold, at least temporarily; even county's Republican chairman, John F Nolan, fails to support Solomon on matter; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Woe is the actor's life: judgment, rejection, humiliation. No wonder Lena is angry. She is angry at the people who assess her at auditions. She is angry at Jorge (David Zayas), the neglectful agent who hasn't bothered to check on her three call backs as a candidate to star on Broadway opposite Andy Garcia in ''Castro.'' And she is angry at her boyfriend, Mike (Gary Perez), who is in the midst of giving up his own acting ambitions to take a steady job, so they can get married and have children, a decent apartment and health insurance.

headline.main: The Actor's Life for Them: Auditions and Rejections

docs.abstract: Lawrence Van Gelder reviews movie Lena's Dreams, written and directed by Heather Johnston and Gordon Eriksen (M)
